bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 27, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the problem in choosing a representative of nursing and of pharmacy for the Wyeth Company portrait series.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 27, 1942

opener.dateline:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
March 27, 1942.

div1.p:
First, let me say that I have purchased the Dorothea Lynde
Dix Memorial, the first of many prepared by her for various
state legislatures and the United States Congress itself. A
small amount of this memorial is quoted in my “Life” of Miss
Dix but now, since looking over the complete Memorial I
believe that it will supply me with a very accurate descrip-
tion of what Cornwell should paint. Incidentally, down at
Wyeth's they feel that in addition to having the “Pioneer”
series include one nurse they should also include one pharm-
acist. It is just as difficult to find a single outstanding
pharmacist as it has been to find an outstanding nurse.
Contributions by Pharmacy to Medicine have been very great
but as far as I can find out, Dr. Procter, who has been
immortalized with a bust in the Hall of Pharmacy in Washington
as father of American Pharmacy is entirely unknown by the
practicing pharmacist. They know only one great name in
Pharmacy and that is Remington, whose outstanding contribution
seems to have been the text book which all the boys studied
in school.

In the field of nursing, as I may have told you, every editor
of the nursing journals has some pet nurse in the history of
the profession always not heard of by the other groups. Clara
Barton's name, known by every school boy, is anathema because
she opposed the training of nurses. Inasmuch as the nurses
themselves know very little about Dorothea Lynde Dix who was
neither for nor against the training of nurses, but who did
act as the head of the Army Nursing Service for some time dur-
ing the Civil War, she seems to be a pretty safe choice, but
her real contribution was in the field of sociology.

There were four or five physicians who had done splendid work
in the United States, all in their chosen field, that of the
insane and feeble-minded. Their influence, however, was re-
stricted to the individual institutions in which they worked.
Miss Dix became a friend and deciple of all of these men dur-
ing the first 2 or 3 years in which she applied herself to
this subject. Following this tutelage under physicians her
influence then next became nationwide extending even to Europe.
It is she who has been credited with arrousing the interest of
not only the layman but most of the medical profession in the
study and care of the insane and feeble-minded.

I can think of no nurse either here or in Europe that even
approached her in influence and accomplishment in her chosen
field other than of course the mightily publicized Florence
Nightingale. As I understand it, Florence Nightingale never
stood in her own light. On the contrary, Miss Dix might have
been much better known had she not been so insistent that not
only no biography be written of herself during her lifetime
but that with the exception of one named for her father no one
of the many institutions which she founded should be named for
her.

I am writing you this partly because I think you might be in-
terested and partly because in my own mind I am trying to re-
evaluate her status as the proper representative of nursing in
the “Pioneer” series.

Dr. Sigerist, who probably knows very little about the history
of nursing and yet who probably knows much more than the average
physician, agreed with me that she was quite acceptable for the
place. Before we actually start to work I may consult him again.
I am sorry that the only biography was written by a very pious
person who never let his heroine step out of the role of a god-
anointed virgin. She must have had some faults or weaknesses but
not according to her biographer.

In reply to your letter of the 20th, the only way I can see that
the calcium subject can be properly discussed is in person. I
am leaving for Chicago on Monday night, the 30th, and will get
in touch with you by 'phone from there on the 2nd. Perhaps you
will be able to give me a little time in Rochester at the end
of that week. Until that time please keep the material that I
sent.

Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
